page.title: 08Pound Farm, Sandridge
page.content: Pound Farm and Hillend Farm were bought by the Salvation Army in 1923, although there has been a farm on this land for at least 400 years.The two farms consist of 928 acres,forming a mixed farm with mainly arable crops but some cattle are kept for beef.The main crops grown are wheat, barley, oats, beans, oil seed rape (used in the manufacture of margarine) and 35 acres of grass which is used for hay or sileage. Barley is used to feed the cattle,the wheat and oats are sold to a large company which makes breakfast cereals. In 1985 2 tons of wheat were sent to the Ethiopian Famine Appeal.A small part of the land is used as grazing for ten horses. The 70 steers, Friesians and cross-bred Angus and Friesians,are kept indoors to avoid being worried by dogs. Protein blocks supplement the cattle's diet.
